siteMetadata.title: Cooking In Pajamas
siteMetadata.description: Stories and Musings from Wayfaring Adventurers and Aspiring Home Cooks.

ghostPost.title: Gettin' your morning BUZZ
ghostPost.html:
To be completely honest... this song isn't quite perfect for this post but it was the first one that came to mind for this post. Enjoy :P

And no, in case you were wondering... I didn't spike these coffee cupcakes with cocaine.

So, I'm not sure how many of you know this but coffee cake doesn't ACTUALLY have any coffee in it... I KNOW! I was just as disappointed as you are right now. Despite these cakes being a COMPLETE and utter lie, I love them down to the very last crumb.

Deceit aside, this recipe was actually quite easy to make and also involved me having to make extra crumble topping to replace the amount I ate. I'd recommend doing the same for yourself :P hehe

NOTE: My crumble topping came out kind of clumpy but I think that was mainly because I got lazy and didn't add the ingredients one by one as described in the recipe. Instead, I decided to add everything at the same time and mix it. It doesn't really change the taste that much but I imagine the cinnamon sugar taste is more uniformly present if you make it right.

Since I didn't really make a custom version of this recipe check out the recipe here.

Try the recipe out yourself and let me know what you think!!!

was the first one that came to mind for this post. Enjoy :P

Deceit aside, this recipe was actually quite easy to make and also involved me

NOTE: My crumble topping came out kind of clumpy but I think that was mainly
because I got lazy and didn't add the ingredients one by one as described in the

doesn't really change the taste that much but I imagine the cinnamon sugar taste
is more uniformly present if you make it right.

Since I didn't really make a custom version of this recipe check out the recipe 
here [http://damndelicious.net/2014/03/24/coffee-cake-muffins/].

Try the recipe out yourself and let me know what you think!!!

previous.html:
Since I'm starting to like theming my blog posts to songs, enjoy.

Let's be honest... Anytime anyone sees their local Girl Scouts at the grocery store, they start drooling and daydreaming of Thin Mints, Tagalongs, Samoa's, and Do-si-Dos. Girl Scout cookies are some of my favorite type of cookies in the world. While I may mainly be a fan of the plain shortbread cookies, Trefoils. Thin mints and Samoa's are America's two favorites.

While plunging into the depths of Pinterest one day, I found a recipe for mini samoa donuts. That got me thinking... What if I were to make mini girl scout themed cupcakes. And to make them even better, give them a slight "adult" twist.

Not to toot my own horn, but these donut bites were AMAZING. Although they were really donuts... but rather cupcakes. They still tasted great. There was definitely not enough alcohol in any of the desserts to do any damage but the slight bourbon taste in the caramel brought out some awesome flavors.

My cousins and I even had a hard time not finishing up the caramel bourbon sauce before the donuts were ready. We kept eating spoon by spoon of the creamy booze-ness.

Pro Tip: Drizzle some warm caramel bourbon sauce onto a scoop of ice cream... HEAVEN.

When I took these desserts to work, they were gone within minutes. Clearly everyone else was dying to get their Girl Scout cookie fix like I was. I even saw this guy spooning caramel bourbon sauce into his coffee to make it a little more "Irish." ;)

Here are the recipes for the donut bites. Even if you don't make the bites themselves... you DEFINITELY have to try the Caramel Bourbon sauce. It takes a few minutes to make and is EXTREMELY rewarding.

Samoa Donut Bites

Ingredients:

Donuts:

  • 1¼ cup all-purpose flour
  • ½ tsp salt
  • 1¼ tsp baking powder
  • 1 tsp vanilla extract
  • 1 egg
  • ½ cup milk
  • ½ tbsp lemon juice
  • 2 tbsp butter, melted
  • 4 tbsp Southern Comfort Caramel

    • Caramel Bourbon Sauce

  • 1 package melting caramel (about 14 oz)
  • 3 tbsp milk
  • ¼ tsp salt
  • 2 tbsp Souther Comfort Caramel
    •   <h4>Toppings</h4>
  <li class="ingredient">3 cups unsweetened coconut flakes, toasted</li>
</div>
<div class="right">
  <h3 id="directions">Directions:</h3>
  <div class="instructions">
    <p>Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Spray the cupcake pan with cooking spray and keep it aside.</p>
    <p>Mix milk and lemon juice in a cup/bowl and let it sit for at least 5 minutes to make buttermilk</p>
    <p><strong>Donuts: </strong>Mix the flour, sugar, baking powder and salt together. Then stir in the vanilla, egg, buttermilk, and melted butter until just mixed. Pour the mixture into the cupcake pan and bake for 4-5 minutes or until done.</p>
    <p><strong>Caramel Icing: </strong>In a separate bowl, warm the caramel with the milk and 1/4 tsp salt. Every 25 seconds, stir the mixture until the caramel is fully melted. Add a few shots of the Southern Comfort Caramel until you feel like your caramel is boozy enough. Feel free to go as crazy as you want.</p>
    <p>Drizzle or dip your donuts in the icing, cool, and enjoy! Even feel free to toss a few toasted coconut flakes on top to make it even more "samoa"-esque</p>
  </div>
</div>

    Whole Wheat Thin Mint Donut Bites

    Ingredients:

    Donuts:

  • ¾ cup milk
  • 1 tsp lemon juice
  • 1 cup + 2 tbsp flour
  • ¼ cup sugar
  • 1 tsp baking powder
  • ½ tsp baking soda
  • 1 tbsp cocoa powder
  • ½ tsp salt
  • 2 tbsp melted butter
  • 1 tsp vanilla extract
  • 1 egg
    •   <h4>Mint Icing</h4>
  <li class="ingredient">1½ cups chocolate chips</li>
  <li class="ingredient">1 tsp oil</li>
  <li class="ingredient">1 tsp vanilla extract</li>
  <li class="ingredient">Crème de menthe</li>
</div>
<div class="right">
  <h3 id="directions">Directions:</h3>
  <div class="instructions">
    <p>Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Spray the cupcake pan with cooking spray and keep it aside.</p>
    <p>Mix milk and lemon juice in a cup/bowl and let it sit for at least 5 minutes to make buttermilk</p>
    <p><strong>Donuts: </strong>Mix the flour, sugar, salt, melted butter, baking soda, baking powder, cocoa powder, and vanilla together. Mix the eggs into this mixture until the batter is fully mixed. Add the buttermilk and when mixed, pour into the cupcake pan and bake for 6-8 minutes or until done throughout.</p>
    <p><strong>Mint Icing: </strong>In a separate bowl, mix all the ingredients together until smooth. Feel free to add as much creme de menthe as you want. Just make sure not to add too much because it'll make the icing too "liquidy."</p>
    <p>Drizzle or dip your donuts in the icing, cool, and enjoy!</p>
  </div>
</div>
previous.title: Dirty Girls Scouts ;)

next.html:
About a week ago we had a parfait event at work to raise awareness about Women in Tech. A lot of people attended and learned a lot about what Box is doing to improve the gender disparity in tech. Sadly, we overestimated how much granola we needed and ended up with 2 GIANT bowls of granola left over.

In my head, it seemed like I could bake those into some variety of oatmeal cookies and breakfast bars and be done with it. No matter how much granola I used, it seemed like it was never going to end! Thankfully after making 3-4 batches of these oatmeal bars I finished 1 bowl, but I ended up making some dark chocolate fruit and nut clusters as well (post coming soon).

In all honesty, these cookie bars were SO much better than those chocolate clusters (as scrumptious as those look). The crumbly-ness and chocolatey-ness of these bars complemented each other perfectly. I've actually saved all the extra crumbles to top ice scream sundaes. Think about how delicious that would be!!! Now that you're officially drooling thinking about that, here's the recipe.

Oatmeal Chocolate Chip Cookie Bars

Ingredients:

  • 3 cups granola (or oats)
  • 1¼ cup butter, melted
  • 2 cups chocolate chips
  • 2 cups flour
  • 1½ cups brown sugar
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 1½ tbsp vanilla
  • 2 eggs

    • Directions:

    Heat oven to 350 degrees. Spray a cookie sheet with non-stick cooking spray.

    Add everything but the chocolate chips into a bowl and mix until just combined. I don't have a standing mixer or this would have been much easier and less messier. Stir in the chocolate chips.

    Spread the batter into the baking dish. Bake for 25 minutes or until a tester comes out with just a few moist crumbs. Bars should look slightly underdone. Let cool 1 hour before cutting into bars. (But let's be honest here... I couldn't wait more than 10 minutes)

    Because the granola I used wasn't very sweet it didn't overly sweeten the bars either, which was something I preferred. Similarly, using brown sugar instead of normal granular sugar kept the bars less sweet. Make sure not to overcook the bars or they won't be as gloriously crumbly!
next.title: What to do when you have the World's Supply of Granola at your Disposal
